articles.title: In a Hotter World, Some People Age Faster, Researchers Find
articles.summary: In a hotter world, some people age faster. Two years of exposure to heat waves could speed up a person's so-called biogenesis. Scientists analyzed 15 years' worth of health data from nearly 25,000 adults in Taiwan and found that living through extreme heat waves can accelerate your rate of aging.

articles.title: Repeated heat wave exposure tied to accelerated aging, with rural and manual workers most affected
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Years of repeated exposure to heat waves may accelerate aging, particularly among elderly people.      Â   for heatwaves may also accelerate aging among people who have been exposed to them for a long time, especially during heat waves.  For more information, visit the National Institute of Health website.

articles.title: Study finds Americans misjudge climate impacts
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Study finds Americans misjudge climate impacts. People often tie things like driving a car to climate change, but a new study finds something as simple as owning a dog could also be hurting the environment, according to a study by the University of Michigan.

articles.title: Cork community fears coast road will be destroyed for a fourth time without protective measures
articles.author: Sean O Riordan
articles.summary: Residents of Pilmore Cottages near Youghal fear the only road leading to their homes will be cut off once more due to coastal erosion. Cork County Council is conducting a study on the region's coasts and how erosion is impacting land. Local Fianna Fáil councillor Patrick Mulcahy is concerned about the future of the Pilmore householders.

articles.title: 'Unexpected' Slowdown in Arctic Sea Ice Melt Stuns Researchers
articles.author: Leslie Eastman
articles.summary: A group of researchers found a 20-year slowdown in the melting of Arctic sea ice in the last 20 years. The scientists used computer models and are inclined to support the pseudoscience of man-caused climate change. They assert that the melting will speed up once 'natural climate variations' end.

articles.title: Residents resort to desperate measures as homes sink with the sand: 'You're just buying time; it's not a fix forever'
articles.author: Nicole Westhoff
articles.summary: Beach erosion is increasing in Ocean Isle Beach, North Carolina. The Army Corps of Engineers was unable to complete a beach re-nourishment project this year, leaving residents to protect their homes with sandbags. Long-term protection goes beyond sandbags, communities are investing in flood-resilient infrastructure and restoring wetlands.

articles.title: Virginia Beach Fishing Pier damaged by Hurricane Erin
articles.author: Daily Press
articles.summary: Hurricane Erin knocked down one of the Virginia Beach Fishing Pier's original piles last week. Roughly 400 feet of the pier remains open for fishing and crabbing, but repairs will need to be made to the pier.   .

articles.title: Towards flood resilience
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: 739 people died, 2,400 houses were damaged or destroyed, and 978 people were injured during the monsoon season of 2025. Pakistan needs to implement urgent emergency relief and go beyond relief to embed protective measures in its policy, planning and long-term rehabilitation strategies.

articles.title: Ruby-throated hummingbird fall migration begins
articles.author: Celeste Silling NATURE NOTES
articles.summary: Gulf Coast Bird Observatory is preparing for its annual Xtreme Hummingbird Xtravaganza on Sept. 13 and 20. The fall ruby-throated hummingbird migration has already begun. They breed as far north as central Canada and spend the winter in Mexico and Central America.

articles.title: Grande Prairie Forest Area Wildfire rating returns to high
articles.author: Nathaniel Leigh
articles.summary: There is a long-duration heat event in Grande Prairie Forest Area Wildfire rating has returned to High. Four of the six fires currently burning in the area are under control, while the other two are listed as being held. Alberta Wildfire is encouraging everyone to do their part to reduce wildfires.

articles.title: In new survey most Delawareans worried about climate change
articles.author: Charlie Sokaitis
articles.summary: According to a new survey, most people in Delaware are worried about climate change. Results from the survey will be incorporated into Delaware's 2025 Climate Action Plan. Public information and input sessions for the 2025 plan will be held in each county this month. The survey was administered to 1,520 Delaware residents via phone, text and online between Feb. 5-18, 2025.

articles.title: Chilliwack heat wave had 3 record-breaking days in a row
articles.author: Jennifer Feinberg
articles.summary: Chilliwack experienced three days of record-breaking, sweat-inducing heat over the weekend. The temperature reached 35 degrees on the second day of the heat wave, which was 10.7 degrees above normal. Relative humidity was only 15%. The previous daily record high for the date was 33.4 C in 2022.

articles.title: Europe's summer wildfires break terrifying record as 1 MILLION hectares scorched
articles.author: Nada Farhoud
articles.summary: This year's European wildfire season has been the worst on record. More than one million hectares have burned in the EU this year, breaking the previous record of 988,544 hectares set in 2017. The infernos have pumped 37m tonnes of CO2 into the atmosphere, about as much as the yearly CO2 emissions of Portugal or Sweden.

articles.title: Toba Supervolcano Nearly Made Humans Go Extinct 70,000 Years Ago: Study
articles.author: Aparna Parameswaran
articles.summary: In 2022, the total human population reached 8 billion people and is projected to reach 9 billion around 2037. About 70,000 years ago, a global disaster, likely caused by the Toba supervolcano, reduced the human population to only a few thousand individuals. There are ongoing debates about the effects of the latest Toba eruption on early humans.

articles.title: Seagulls are reaching plague proportions outside Parliament House, harassing staff and visitors
articles.author: Monte Bovill
articles.summary: Hundreds of seagulls have been converging on parliament's forecourt. The birds have been harassing visitors and staff. Landscapers covered the grevilleas on the island in the middle of the forecourt with grow cloths to deter them from nesting there. Ornithologist Chris Davey is keeping a close eye on Spinnaker Island.

articles.title: In the Arctic, consequences of heat waves linger
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Temperatures in Siberia reached 6C above the norm during the first half of 2020. The situation climaxed in the second half of the year 2020.   Â      in the third year of 2020, the average monthly temperature reached 7.5C.

articles.title: B.C. town reaches hottest temperature Canada has seen all year
articles.summary: It was 40.3˚C in Lytton, B.C. yesterday, which is the hottest day in Canada since 2025. The town is hosting Labour Day celebrations this weekend. In June 2021, the town was even hotter, reaching a staggering 49.6°C.

articles.title: Letter: Climate change and the Canadian wildfires
articles.summary: Some Republican members of Congress sent a letter to the Canadian government, accusing them of poor forest management practices and out-of-control wildfires. According to Natural Resources Canada, climate change is impacting the frequency, size and range of wildland fires in Canada. 184 medical and public health groups have released a statement declaring climate change a public health emergency.

articles.title: Climate Change and Disaster Management
articles.author: Sajid Salamat
articles.summary: Pakistan was recently hit by massive floods which caused severe damage in major cities of the country. Climate change is no longer a myth for Pakistan as it is a clear threat to the masses. The South Asian monsoon is a lifeline for agriculture in Pakistan, but with changing climate dynamics, it has turned into a recurring threat. The monsoon floods of 2010, 2014 and 2022 were among the most devastating natural disasters in Pakistan's history. According to official estimates, over 33 million people were affected, more than 1,700 lives were lost and economic damages exceeded $30 billion.

articles.title: Nearly 9 in 10 Austin kids learn in dangerous heat zones, study finds
articles.author: Brandon Watson
articles.summary: The majority of K-12 public school students in Austin learn in extreme urban heat zones, according to a new report from Climate Central. Texas schools need to spend $162,652,000 updating HVAC systems in 5,678 schools by the end of 2025. Houston has the highest percentage of students learning in extreme heat zones.

articles.title: Study reveals surprising carbon pawprint: How your dog's diet affects climate change
articles.author: Liz Mclaughlin
articles.summary: A new study by the National Academy of Sciences found that many people focus on the wrong actions when it comes to combating climate change. People often overestimate the benefits of small, visible steps such as recycling and underestimate the emissions from larger lifestyle choices, such as flying, using renewable energy and owning a dog. The study found that dogs are among the top three personal lifestyle choices contributing to greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Widespread Anti-Israel Protests Held in Australia
articles.author: The Algemeiner
articles.summary: Thousands of Australians joined anti-Israel rallies on Sunday. Relations between Israel and Australia have been strained since the Gaza conflict in 2014.    The march is called 'Nationwide March for Palestine' and takes place in Sydney on August 24, 2025. It is organized by the Palestine Solidarity Movement.

articles.title: Local, state officials say drought and heat threats to Yuma ag, water
articles.author: Kawc
articles.summary: Current and former elected officials met with food safety experts in Yuma on Friday as part of the Extreme Weather Emergency Tour. Their message was that climate change is a threat to the Colorado River and the ag economy in Arizona. They called on Arizona residents to contact their local and federal elected officials and ask them to not support any more cuts to ag programs.

articles.title: 'Action on the ground': local councils vital to minimising natural disasters
articles.author: Lauren Richardson
articles.summary: The Northern Midlands Council endorsed in principle its Climate Resilience Strategy 2025-2028 in June 2025. The council identified itself as providers, facilitators and advocates in an effort to respond to increased impacts from climate change. The Northern Tasmanian Alliance for Resilient Councils (NTARC) is funded with almost $1 million to assist the councils in understanding and responding to regional hazards and disasters over the next three years. Over a third of the money is being raised by the councils.

articles.title: Central Alberta under heat wave expected to last all week
articles.author: rdnews NOW staff
articles.summary: Red Deer and much of central Alberta will be under a heat event that's expected to last over the next seven days. The daytime high temperatures are expected to reach 29 to 33 degrees Celsius. The overnight low temperatures will range between 9 to 13 degrees. Residents should reschedule outdoor activities to the morning or evening when temperatures are cooler.

articles.title: Late August heatwave sets records
articles.author: Kelowna Courier Staff
articles.summary: The water temperature in Okanagan Lake is rising due to a late August heatwave. The lake is warmer than the waters off Los Angeles (21.8 C) and San Diego (22.3 C). The lake has warmed up a degree or so in the past few days. Daytime temperature records were set Sunday in Kelowna, Princeton and 18 other B.C. towns and cities.

articles.title: FEMA employees say Trump policies are undermining disaster response in open letter
articles.summary: More than 180 current and former FEMA employees published the Katrina Declaration on Aug. 25, warning of a catastrophe like Hurricane Katrina. They petitioned Congress to establish FEMA as a cabinet-level independent agency, protect it from Department of Homeland Security interference, and sent the declaration to the FEMA Review Council and congressional committees dedicated to disaster survivors.

articles.title: Minnesota gets an early fall preview with cool, dry week
articles.author: Meteorologist Sven Sundgaard
articles.summary: Sven Sundgaard is back with a look at a cool, dry week ahead in Minnesota. Sunday's high of 69 was the coolest August high temp in 7 years. Monday morning's low was coolest since May 26. IPCC has warned Earth is "firmly on track toward an unlivable world" and says greenhouse gas emissions must be halved by 2030 to limit warming to 1.5C.

articles.title: The Best Climate-Focused Speculative Fiction
articles.author: Leah Von Essen
articles.summary: Climate change and related disasters are becoming a daily reality for people around the world. Many science fiction authors are focusing on the near future to imagine how we might survive, grieve and adapt in the midst of climate change. The best climate fiction also grapples with humanity's resilience and what it takes to preserve hope when all hope is seemingly lost.

articles.title: Katrina archives: New Orleans levees 'very haphazard' compared to Dutch flood systems
articles.author: John McQuaid
articles.summary: The Netherlands has built a world-class flood defense system. It's 50 times safer than New Orleans levees before Hurricane Katrina. U.S. Sen. Mary Landrieu will visit the Netherlands next month to learn more about the Dutch flood protection system.

articles.title: Africa demands climate justice as warming accelerates across continent
articles.author: Business
articles.summary: African leaders gathered in Addis Ababa on Monday to demand urgent global action on climate change. The Fifth International Symposium on Climate Justice brought together government ministers, diplomats and activists. It highlighted Africa's disproportionate vulnerability to a crisis largely caused by industrialized nations. The gathering also launched the fifth cohort of the Nairobi Summer School for Climate Justice, designed to train young African negotiators for international climate talks.

articles.title: Things to think about before you next wade through floodwaters
articles.author: Simar Bajaj
articles.summary: Climate change is intensifying both hurricanes and everyday storms, making flooding events more common and more severe. Heavy rain can overwhelm streams and streets with little to no warning, both along coasts and inland. All it takes is 6 inches (15cm) of fast-moving water to flood a street.

articles.title: Heat warnings in effect for B.C.'s north and central coast, parts of Interior
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Environment Canada says the Victoria area saw a high of 31.1 degrees, breaking a record from over 100 years ago. Lytton recorded 38.6 degrees. A heat warning remains in place for inland regions of the North Coast including Terrace and Kitimat.

articles.title: Spain Heatwave: 1100+ Deaths in Record-Breaking Heat
articles.summary: This year's European heatwave shattered previous temperature records. Over 1,100 deaths were attributed to a scorching heatwave in Spain this summer. Scientists predict that heatwaves will become more common, longer-lasting, and more severe in the coming decades due to climate change. Europe's infrastructure is ill-equipped to handle the escalating heat, roads buckle, railway lines warp, and power grids strain under the increased demand for cooling. Farmers need to adopt climate-resilient agricultural practices, such as drought-resistant crops, efficient irrigation systems, and agroforestry techniques. Innovative insurance models are struggling to keep pace with the escalating costs of climate-related disasters.

articles.title: ‘Like the corn's never getting a break. It's just hot all the time': How America's farmers conquered climate change for a ‘monster' harvest

articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: paradox: Earth's vegetation cover has expanded, but there is no increase in the Earth's landmass.    for more information on the study here. articles.title: 21 temperature records broken or tied as thermometers soar across B.C.
articles.author: Black Press Media Staff
articles.summary: Twenty-one communities in B.C. broke or tied temperature records on Sunday. The hottest spot was Lytton at 40.3 C, breaking a 1958 record of 28.9 C. The Cache Creek area was the second-hottest spot with a new record of 38.2 C. Lillooet tied the 2022 record of 37.4 C, followed by 36.8 C in Kamloops and 36.7 C in Princeton.

articles.title: The Number of People Exposed to Wildfires Nearly Doubles, with Africa Bearing the Greatest Burden
articles.author: United Nations University
articles.summary: There were at least 2,500 deaths and 10,500 injuries directly from wildfires and 1.5 million smoke-related deaths each year in the first two decades of the 21st century. Human exposure to wildland fires increased 40% (2002-2021) despite a 26% decline in burned area. Climate change caused a 54% increase in extreme fire weather, longer fire seasons, and increased night-time flammability. Africa accounted for 85% of those exposed.

articles.title: Spain Records Most Intense Heatwave in History Amid Wildfires
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: This August's heatwave in Spain was the most intense on record, both in terms of temperatures and impacts. This year's heatwaves have caused 1,149 deaths, while the extreme heat coincided with Spain's worst month of wildfires on record. 406,100 hectares of land, roughly 5.5 times the size of Singapore, have been burned by the fires.

articles.title: Study: Enduring heat waves makes us age faster
articles.author: Lisa Hornung
articles.summary: Two years of exposure to heat waves can speed aging by 8 to 12 days. Manual workers are more vulnerable to faster aging because of heat. The U.S. West Coast is suffering from very high temperatures, and Iran has extreme heat. In 2024, the hottest year on record, climate change caused 41 extra days of extreme heat worldwide.

articles.title: Human 'Stuff' Now Outweighs All Life on Earth
articles.author: Slashdot
articles.summary: According to a new study, the mass of all our stuff now exceeds the weight of all living things on the planet. The amount of new material added every week equals the total weight of Earth's nearly 8 billion people. Fossil fuels have sent greenhouse gases soaring to levels not seen in at least 800,000 years. Agriculture and dwellings have altered 70% of land and humans have wiped out untold numbers of species.

articles.title: Why climate change is making salmonella outbreaks more common
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Salmonella outbreaks are expected to become more common due to climate change, according to new research. It was originally published on talker.news, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange, and is republished here on Stephen Beech’s request.

articles.title: Boats moor at port in S China's Hainan for shelter as Typhoon Kajiki intensifies
articles.summary: Typhoon Kajiki has reached Sanya City, south China's Hainan Province. All 30,769 local fishing boats have returned to port or are sheltering safely. Over 21,000 crew members moved to the shore. Typhoon is the 13th of the year.

articles.title: Heatwaves are making people age faster, study suggests
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Exposure to high temperatures could cause long-lasting damage to health of billions of people, scientists warn. Repeated exposure to heatwaves is accelerating ageing in people, according to a study. The impact is broadly comparable with the effects of global warming.

articles.title: FEMA employees draft formal declaration of dissent
articles.summary: On the 20th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, 182 Federal Emergency Management Agency employees submitted a formal declaration of dissent to members of Congress. The Katrina Declaration warns that the stripping of FEMA's statutory authorities places American communities in grave danger. The signatories denounce the censorship of climate science, the removal of vital risk data from public access, and the improper and abrupt reassignment of FEMA employees to Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

articles.title: Why climate change is making salmonella outbreaks more common

articles.author: Marcia Annenberg
articles.summary: According to EPA website, Maine has warmed 3 degrees since 1900, spring is arriving earlier with more rain, sea level is rising and causing more flooding, and the ocean is becoming more acidic due to the absorption of carbon dioxide. The years 2015 and 2024 are the warmest since records have been taken.

articles.title: B.C.‘s Fraser Canyon to bake under 39 C heat as wildfire prompts evacuation alerts
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: People cool off in Lynn Creek in North Vancouver, B.C., on Thursday, July 6, 2023. Darryl Dyck is the author of the article. The article is published on The Peterborough Examiner, a website owned by The Canadian Press.

articles.title: Heat Waves Could Speed Up Aging
articles.author: The Scientist
articles.summary: At least 10 countries experienced temperatures higher than 50°C in 2023–2024. With the increasing frequency, duration, and magnitude of heat waves, there is an elevated burden of non-communicable diseases around the world, according to the World Meteorological Organization.

articles.title: Climate disasters are escalating: 6 ways South Africa's G20 presidency can lead urgent action
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: South Africa holds the presidency of the G20. It has set up a Disaster Risk Reduction Working Group to find solutions for climate-induced disasters made worse by poverty and inequality. Olivia Kunguma and Johannes Belle discuss what's needed from G20 this year to make a difference. The G20 has a theme of 'Solidarity, Equality and Sustainability'

articles.title: New wildfire sparks southwest of Nanaimo
articles.author: Nanaimo Bulletin News Staff
articles.summary: A new wildfire started up last night and burned 7.7 hectares southwest of Nanaimo overnight. Manson Creek is considered out of control as of 7:30 a.m. on Monday, August 25. The fire was discovered Sunday, Aug. 24, about two kilometres west of the intersection of Naniamo Lakes Road and South Forks Road. The cause is under investigation.

articles.title: FEMA staffers accuse Trump of weakening disaster programs
articles.author: Zack Colman
articles.summary: Current and former FEMA officials are warning Congress that the Trump administration's policies have undermined the nation's ability to respond to natural disasters like Hurricane Katrina. The message comes ahead of the 20th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, which devastated New Orleans and the Gulf Coast. The 181 signatories say FEMA has abandoned the reforms designed to correct the agency's mistakes in responding to the 2005 hurricane. FEMA spokesperson Daniel Llargues says the administration is making changes to reduce bureaucracy and deliver federal assistance more quickly.

articles.title: FEMA staffers rebuke Trump for weakening disaster programs
articles.author: Zack Colman
articles.summary: Current and former FEMA officials are warning Congress that the Trump administration's policies have undermined the nation's ability to respond to natural disasters like Hurricane Katrina. The message comes ahead of the 20th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, which devastated New Orleans and the Gulf Coast. The current and former staffers called attention to downsizing at the agency and that one-third of FEMA staffers have departed. They also criticized FEMA's efforts to reduce spending programs intended to avert costly disaster damage.

articles.title: In a Hotter World, Some People Age Faster, Researchers Find
articles.summary: Two years of exposure to extreme heat waves can speed up biological aging by 8 to 12 extra days. In 2024, the hottest year on record, climate change was responsible for it. The research comes as human-induced climate change is making the world warmer.

articles.title: Climate action can't wait – and neither can Africa
articles.author: Independent online
articles.summary: Climate change is not a future problem, it's happening now and having dramatic impacts. Climate action is necessary on all fronts, including mitigation, adaptation and coping with impacts and building long-term resilience, says the UNFCCC's chief.

articles.title: In a Hotter World, Some People Age Faster, Researchers Find
articles.author: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
articles.summary: Two years of exposure to extreme heat waves can speed up biological aging by 8 to 12 days, according to research published in the journal Nature Climate Change. Human-induced climate change is making heat waves more intense and long-lasting. In 2024, the hottest year on record, climate change was responsible for 41 extra days of extreme heat worldwide.

articles.title: Heatwaves are making people age faster, study suggests
articles.author: Damian Carrington
articles.summary: Heatwaves accelerate ageing in people, according to a new study. The researchers followed 25,000 people in Taiwan for 15 years and compared their exposure to heatwaves with their biological age, a measure of overall health. They found that the biological age increased by nine days for people who experienced four more heatwave days over a two-year period. Manual workers, who tend to spend more time outside, were strongly affected.

articles.title: NASA says Earth's oxygen is fading, predicts possible timeline
articles.author: Alexander Clark
articles.summary: Recent studies and warnings from NASA have sparked global concern about the long-term sustainability of Earth's oxygen supply. Deforestation, industrial pollution, and urban expansion are reducing the number of trees and plants, which are crucial for photosynthesis, the process that produces oxygen. The burning of fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide, which contributes to global warming and ocean acidification. Oceanic plankton, which contribute to the oxygen supply, are threatened by rising temperatures and pollution. The potential consequences of decreased oxygen levels are vast, affecting both human health and societal functions.

articles.title: Scientists observe unprecedented movement of the magnetic North Pole
articles.summary: Earth's magnetic North Pole is shifting. It has been a gradual process for centuries, but recent observations have revealed a change in the pace of its movement. This has surprising implications for our daily lives, from the way our smartphones work to the navigation of airplanes.

articles.title: Why climate change is making salmonella outbreaks more common
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Salmonella outbreaks are expected to become more common due to climate change, according to new research from the U.S. Department of Health and Humanitarian Aid to the People (HARPA) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) say.

articles.title: Record-breaking heat beats down on Malahat drivers during Sunday commute
articles.summary: Malahat area broke the newest daily heat record on the Island, hitting 30.2 C on Sunday (Aug. 24). Up Island Nanaimo tied the oldest record, hitting a high of 33.3 C. Campbell River, Courtenay and Comox all battled 2016 records. Vancouver Island begins to see a cooling trend starting Monday (Aug 25) with temperatures in Victoria decreasing from 25 C anticipated Monday to 22 C Wednesday.

articles.title: Two Decades of Progress: How Hurricane Katrina Sparked a Revolution in Forecasting
articles.author: NPR
articles.summary: Twenty years after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, advancements in hurricane science have transformed forecasting capabilities. Five-day hurricane track forecasts now possess the accuracy that two-day forecasts held before Katrina. Dr. Gabriel Vecchi, a hurricane and climate scientist at Princeton University, emphasizes the significance of this continuous investment in hurricane research.

articles.title: Where Would Planting Trees Help Most With Global Warming?
articles.author: Carole Tanzer
articles.summary: It's a simple and common prescription for global warming and it's a common and common remedy for it as well. Carole Tanzer Miller is a HealthDay Reporter.    for the HealthDay News.  For more information, go to www.healthdaynews.com.

articles.title: Valérie Masson-Delmotte: 'The climate situation will keep getting worse, but the danger also comes from collective denial'
articles.author: Audrey Garric
articles.summary: Valérie Masson-Delmotte is a climatologist and member of France's High Council on Climate. France has just experienced a long and intense heat wave, the second of the summer. The number of cities recording temperatures over 40°C is symbolic, because heat that intense affects the very conditions for life.

articles.title: Jeremy Clarkson issues brutal verdict on woke parents' 'irritating' kids
articles.author: Holly Fleet
articles.summary: Jeremy Clarkson criticises parents who scare their children about climate change in his latest Sun column. The former Top Gear host is a keen farmer in the Cotswolds and is known for his Amazon farming series Clarkson's Farm. Clarkson's grandchildren visited his Oxfordshire farm and enjoyed the fresh air without being reminded of melting ice caps or wildfires.

articles.title: James City, New Kent to see population booms, researchers say
articles.author: Daily Press
articles.summary: Communities in the Historic Triangle and western Tidewater region will be among the fastest-growing localities in Virginia over the next 25 years, according to University of Virginia population estimates published last month. In July, the Weldon Cooper Center for Public Service at UVA released population projections for the area.

articles.title: Cape Breton farms, stables struggle with 'unprecedented' hot and dry summer weather
articles.author: Ian Nathanson
articles.summary: This summer's hot and dry weather has affected agriculture in Nova Scotia. Donnie MacNeil, owner of Lambscapes Farm and Abattoir in Mill Creek, has had to change how he operates his family farm due to drought. According to Farmers to Farmers Nova Scotia, droughts cut into farming profits due to higher costs and lower yields.

articles.title: Fishermen, residents to stage hartal in Koyilandy over delay in coastal road repair
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Coastal residents and fishermen will observe a dawn-to-dusk hartal on September 1 to protest the delay in repairing the damaged coastal road between Kappad and Koyilandy. They will also take out a march to the office of the MLA demanding urgent action.

articles.title: Drought, taxes pile on pressure
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: Extreme weather and new emergency services taxes are making the mental pressures experienced by farmers harder to bear, say experts. The new taxes are due to be introduced in 2018.   Â. Â   y  y   a   for farmers.

articles.title: East African economies face rising costs of climate extremes
articles.author: Phidel Kizito
articles.summary: Unpredictable weather has disrupted agriculture, displaced millions and strained already fragile economies in recent years. The risks extend beyond agriculture to critical sectors such as hydropower, transport, and insurance. The forum will review the June–September 2025 season and present the consolidated forecast for the October–December period.

articles.title: Climate Models Have Predicted Sea Level Rise Almost Perfectly For 30 Years
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: The extent of sea level rise measured by satellites around the world is in line with what climate models predicted in the 1990s. It's bad news, because what the models anticipate in the future is frightening, but at least it shows our understanding of the climate is good.

articles.title: Climate threats jeopardize growth, investments in greater Horn of Africa: IGAD
articles.author: Phidel Kizito
articles.summary: Ethiopia, Somalia, and Kenya have endured consecutive droughts that decimated livestock and left millions dependent on humanitarian aid. Flash floods in South Sudan and Uganda destroyed infrastructure, triggered disease outbreaks, and reversed development gains. The risks extend beyond agriculture to critical sectors such as hydropower, transport, and insurance. The forum will review the June–September 2025 season and present the consolidated forecast for the October–December period.

articles.title: Warming seas around T�rkiye threaten marine life, biodiversity
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Sea temperatures around T�rkiye have risen faster than the global average, according to scientists. This is causing severe stress to marine ecosystems and threatening species such as seagrasses, they warn. The sea temperatures are also higher than the world's average.

articles.title: Pan African Center for Climate Policy holds major conference
articles.summary: The Pan African Center for Climate Policy is hosting its 3rd Global Conference on Environmental Education and Lifelong Learning from October 16-17, 2025, in Canada. The conference aims to develop a robust climate policy that will serve as a global strategy for adapting to climate change, reducing emissions, safeguarding ecosystems, and ensuring sustainable development. According to the WHO, environmental factors contribute to approximately 13 million deaths annually worldwide.

articles.title: Researchers foresee population booms in James City, New Kent
articles.author: Ben Swenson
articles.summary: Historic Triangle and western Tidewater communities will be among the fastest-growing localities in Virginia over the next 25 years. James City and New Kent counties are predicted to have population growth rates among the highest in Virginia. York County, Williamsburg and King William County are also gaining a significant number of residents.

articles.title: Studies Show Coral Growth Stronger in Warmer, Higher Seas
articles.author: from
articles.summary: Research indicates coral reefs expanded most rapidly during past warm periods when sea levels were higher. Reef islands formed when seas were higher, with higher sea levels providing favorable conditions for coral expansion. Modern reef declines are often associated with bleaching events, such as the 1998 episode linked to El Niño.

articles.title: Zambia: Amid Worsening Droughts and Crop Failure, Zambians Call for Collective Climate Action
articles.author: Edward Chibwili

articles.title: Record drought in Europe, Med in early August
articles.author: Agence France-Presse . Paris
articles.summary: 51.3% of Europe and the Mediterranean basin was affected by drought in the first ten days of August. Caucasus and north Balkans regions were most affected by the drought, with Georgia and Armenia affected on 97% of their territory, followed by Bulgaria and Kosovo. Serbia, North Macedonia, Albania, Hungary and Montenegro all saw three quarters of their surface area put on warning or alert. Central Europe saw the only improvement.
